item.title: The indigenous attribution of agency
item.description: In the indigenous worldview, vegetal life is granted agency and even personhood, and is treated with respect and reverence accordingly. item.title: Our best defense against stupidity is diversity
item.description: Appealing as it is want an expert in charge, the last thing we need is a committee of enlightened despots ruling the world. item.title: Retributive justice does not work
item.description: Behaviorism claims that the only thing powerful enough to spur people into action is the promise of reward or the fear of punishment. The most widely understood theoretical model of how punishment works comes from behaviorist psychology, which looks at punishment as one kind of conditioning.

item.title: Core values
Getting clear on your core values prevents manipulation
item.description: One of the most valuable things I learned in therapy is how to define my own core values and principles. Get very clear on what drives you, and what you believe in as a set of principles, not ideology, and then use that as your guide to navigate the world.

item.title: Disgust is a culture-bound syndrome
item.description: Symbolic disgust is subjective, not objective, and is a [[notes/pms and other pathologies are culture-bound syndromes|culture-bound syndrome]]. item.title: Moral dumbfounding is not moral reasoning
item.description: Moral judgement and moral reasoning are basically two different processes.
